On tap at a local japanese restaurant. it paired well with some of the dishes, benefitting from the subtle spice and flaming hot, straight-off-the-grill temperature of the takoyaki

On tap at Genghis Grill.  A pale yellow pour with a small foamy head and minimal lacing.  Smells of light malt and hops.  Better than a typical macro American lager.  The crispness went well with the spicy food.
regular bland lager, yellow to much carbonation, grassy nose, flavor is rice wheat and stale hops, ok lager
good beginner beer, but if you like a hoppy, strong and/or flavorful beer, this ain’t for you
Nice and Light. Would have it at any Japanese Steakhouse! I liked the bubbles always rising to the top.
Pores like a typical pale lager, flavor was lite with little bitterness. Lite malt flavor with a nice balance of sweat to bitter. Not bad.

Pours a yellow straw with a soapy foam head that laces. Smells of faint warm sake and grain. Tastes of watery malt and not much else. A little bite that reminds me of hops. Light in the mouth and drinkable for colored water. To be honest, its not that bad it just doesnt boast craft beer flavor. It does compliment my sushi very well being that its refreshing and renews the palate for picking out the subtle delicious flavors of the nigiri at hand.

This is not bad, has fairly strong flavour, and seems to be one of the better macro Japanese lagers.  It is better than Sapporo or Asahi and closer to  the Chinese Tsingtao (the regular, not pure draft), but is more bland and watery.  It’s gold with a medium white head that dissipates to a ring & wisps.  The aroma is largely a standard pale lager smell, but fairly full and rich for the style, with malty grain, sweetness, and a hint of pine.  The taste is similar, being a good, solid pale lager taste, light malty sweetness, a hint of pine bitterness, a hint of fruitiness, and a lightly toasted grain aftertaste.  It’s still rather watery and bland, but has decent flavour and balance and is very drinkable and pleasant.
Definitily a macrobrew, nothing to special about it.  Pretty much the same as american pale lagers.

(Bottle) Initially has some bite of hops, but there’s an unpleasant muted taste, like a typical macro.  Tastes better when you drink it on its own than with food...with food it really comes out how this brew is much too sweet.

Light amber with a weak head. The aroma is neutral and the flavour is mild with notes of hops, honey and flower. The bitterness is weak. Harmless and quickly forgotten, but probably nice for beginners in the world of beer.
Light amber in color, no head. Aroma: Foul. Tastes like lousy beer...moving right along. Beers of the World ’07.

Bottle.  Poured to a clear golden color with a qucik flyffu qhite head that disappeared as quick as it formed.  Very fizzy and a faint aroma.  Very thin body and watery.  Clean & lite with little to no flavor.  Quick beginning, fast middle and end.  After taste was confusing: bitter, sour and acidic.
Tap. Golden, small lacy head. Fresh malty nose, nicely full maltiness and even smooth hoppy flavor. Good.

On tap. Don’t recall appearance or aroma being special in anyway. Palate was thin with lively carbonation. Taste was bad, with  an strong unpleasant flavour that I cannot compare with normal beer flavours -  bitter but in a metallic unpleasant way. One to avoid.

[bottle for an Asian supermarket in Marburg]
Typical German pils aroma that is a nice balance of crisp base malt and fresh noble hops.  Bright gold with white fizz that drops quickly to a wispy cover and dense ring.  Sort of tangy sweet malt flavour that is not balanced out with enough bitterness.  The hops seem not quite fresh, either.  Light to medium body, medium carbonation, rancidy finish.
Draught. Sour corn aroma. Clear with slow rising carbonation. Biting palate, sharp and intrusive. Sour flavor that makes me unhappy.

Hmm - brewed by Anheuser Busch.  So that is why it is available all over the place.  But to what degree is this American megabrewer product, and to what degree is it Kirin?  Let’s have a look.  Nice Japanese label (no Clydesdales here).  Mild aroma with a little sweetness.  Light flavor with hints of citrus, yeast, and rice.  A little more flavor than most Asian warm weather beers, and pretty refreshing overall.
This was a surprise. Different than other Asian Beers I have had. A real American flavor. It is a good Pale but nothing spectacular.

This is a pretty mild beer for an import, but definitely not a "light" beer because it has flavor.  It has a mild hops presence and goes down very easily.  Like most pale lagers this won’t appeal to the NBS.  I think it’s great.

Bottle at Bieres et Saveurs Chambly. The color is honey with no head. The taste weel mostly of colored water. I regreted  asking and having to pay for this one the moment I took a sip. This was not beer.
This is junk light beer.  I only get it because this is about what they have when I go out for sushi.  I was unaware it was brewed by AB, but it makes a lot of sense.  Poop.
This is Budweiser.  There is no discernable difference between Kirin Ichiban and Bud from the tap.  Same aroma, same flavor, same mouthfeel.  Same mass-produced junk.
smelled good from what i could tell.  golden color on the pour with a very malty taste and easy on the palate.

Pours a clear golden yellow. Not a noticeable head at all. Aroma was bitter and slightly corny. Tasted like a generic pale lager. Over carbonated, and a heightened taste of rice and malt.  No real hops flavor or anything else. Not terrible, just very mediocre. If you’re going to buy a Japanese Import, buy something else, because this tastes just like the mass-produced lagers from the US.

on tap at Busch Gardens - had no idea what I was ordering, at the time I thought it might actually have some character compared to their other offerings, but I was wrong and very disappointed. Light, fizzy and mostly flavorless. Pretty much the same yellow stuff that AB sticks in a host of blue & red cans. Not even satisfying when your chugging everything in sight in the hopes that you can forget that your outside walking in circles with thousands of other people for no reason.

Oh, it’s brewed by AB! That explains a lot. Palest yellow with a greenish hue, like light olive oil. Starts off having a decent sized head of lumpy white foam; +1 point. Almost no lace. Ashtray, sulphur, and solventy scents… also some yeasty/sour notes. Flavor: brown paper bag.  Less-than-watery mouthfeel with  a spritz of lime juice acidity. Old spit aftertaste. Probably the most worthless "beer" (not!) on the planet. I wish it were possible for zero scores on aroma, flavor, and overall. A glass of air would be more satisfying.
fizzy, yellow, very little taste, typical mass produced lager, not very good.

Inexpensive bomber, plain pale lager. Faint aroma of soft malt, reminds me of a euro lager. Nice light yellow pour with a diminishing white head and nice lacing. Extremely light bodied, drinks like water with a soft finish. Pale malt with a splash of hops. Again this is very similar to the typical imported euro lager. Non-offensive, yet too boring to earn higher marks.
While I have had worse, this didn’t even come close to Asahi or Sapporo at the sushi bar I just went to this evening. It was fizzy and pale yellow in its facade while its taste was very thin.
Not really into the whole asian beer thing but whatever. Nothing special nothing horrible. Pretty plain jane to me. Not much else to say.

12 oz can left over from a party (given to me by a friend):  Light golden color with a medium, fading white head. Aroma is light and flowery with a hint of hop spice. Flavor is lightly tropical fruit sweet with a hint of grass and a lightly bitter, dry finish. Light bodied and oily with moderate carbonation. Suprisingly refreshing and quaffable.

Canned 33cl. It pours a nice golden beer with an average head. A decent nose. Lots of hay in the taste. Biscuitty. Perfectly balanced: The sourness, sweetness and bitterness are perfectly equilibrated. Notes of rice and cereals. Herbal buttery finish.

Can’t believe I haven’t rated this one yet.  It’s a good match for sushi, but not much else.  Straw yellow pour, shrinking white head.  Lots of corn in the flavor.  Taste testing blindfolded, I hope I could distinguish this from a US macro.
12oz bottle.  Aroma is grainy corn/rice and macro skunk.  Average white head that mostly diminished.  Gold hue.  Flavor is crappy grainy, metallic macro swill.  Don’t ever buy this again.

Pours a pale gold with a loose, frothy, white head that diminishes with time, leaving cobweb lace upon the glass. On the nose is a stale pale malt aroma with a distinct note that reminds me of my high school chemistry teachers breath. She smoked menthols, but her "last" cigarette had always been enjoyed a couple hours before she shared its aroma with my class. Bleh.. The mouthfeel is nice enough until the swallow: light bodied but with an almost medium feel, due to the carbonation, it finishes grainy and metallic. I’m not surprised that Bud brews this in The States because it carries some of the marks of their macro-lagers: a rice-like adjunct note, sub-par mouthfeel and a slightly metallic finish. While it may be just a notch above some of ABs stable of regular pale lagers, it is not a beer that I really care to revisit.

Sad that this beer is made by A-B, but hey it is a standard lager with a little Heiniken taste to it. It isn’t an offensive lager like many others and it is easy enough to swill a few of these while watching TV or something. Cool bottle design with the Kirin spirit on it.
I had this in a Thai restaurant with some really spicy Thai dish. I liked it a lot but when I found out it was made by  Anheuser-Busch it lost its appeal.

This beer is very bland and very boring. Very pale/golden pour with a small white head that dissopates quickly, not much of an aroma except for your standard hops and barley scents. Taste is very uninteresting, and not much better than say bud or busch.
Pours a clear yellow color with small white head.No real aroma to it. Slight grainy taste to it. Nothing offensive about this brew,but nothing really to say about it as well.
22 oz. can pours a clean, crisp yellow color with a big malt back bone and mild astringint bite.  Not bad when eating at the hibachi restaurant.
clear yellow pour with a medium sized head. danky hops and malt in the aroma. slightly bitter flavor very thin mouthfeel and bit dry in the end. easy drinker nothing special.

From bottle : Pours a clear gold color with a finger thick fizzy white head.  Nose of malts, with some citrus notes.  Thick for a pale lager.  Has a little malt taste, no sign of any hops, and a nasty aftertaste.  Not good.

330 ml bottle. Dense and stable white head. Crystal clear light golden color. Dry dusty hops to the nose. Whiffs of dry malts and metal. Taste is dry with a low malt profile. Sourish and light bitter notes.  Superlight body. A little grainy sweetness and light bitternesss  in the finish. Easy to drink, easy to forget.
pours pale yellow, with small white head, thin body, almost no aroma, small amount of flavor, not bad, but not that great either
Pale yellow with a thin white head, thin and watery body, average carbonation. Very little flavour and bitterness. Sweet & fizzy. Not terrible but not great.

330ml bottle - labeled Kirin Ichiban First Press Beer 5% Alc/Vol , Pale yellow/gold. Thin, rapidly diminishing white head. Medium carbonation. Thin bodied.  Sweet, slightly malty, Short, finish. Rather average but drinkable.

Not bad for a pale lager and one of the best I’ve tasted from Japan. Aroma was a bit of malt but hard to pick up. Pour was a decent light gold with a one finger white head. Taste was malty for a pale lager. Nice carbonation and a dry and crisp finish. Not a great beer, but a very good pale lager.
Ignoring everything, this beer is all right if you have nothing else to blow your money on. I’m not sure if that makes any sense, but I’ve certainly had worse beers.
(Bottle, at Thai restaurant)  Pours a clear golden body with a small white head.  Light aroma of corn grain and rice.  Flavor of bland hops and some sweetness with a watery mouthfeel.
most fantastic beer ever. i don’t care what you think - as far as i’m concerned, this beer  is the H2O of the gods. jesus drinks kirin - if you don’t, that’s your damn fault.
Well, its a pale lager, so expectations have to be low. Nothing stands out about this beer other than have a slightly cooler can than other beers in the genre.

Premium . . . as far as lager’s go, yes it is premium.  It’s like the horse on the bottle galloped full-force down your nostrils after running over a skunk.  Oh yes, it’s the premium goodness of what looks like a refrigerated, carbonated urine sample.     Wincing eases after realizing that the first swig tastes like nothing, but then there’s that odd metallic aftertaste like I’ve been running outside in the dead of winter.  And then I realize - why, If I do not like this beer, am I writing so much about it?
12 ounce bottle. Shaker glass. Golden with a thin head. Aroma -- not much to speak of. Taste was crisp and slightly bitter with a hint of malt.
Bottle. Aroma of grain... mostly corn and a tiny bit of hops. Pours gold with tiny carbonation. A hint of lemon zest, and grain on the palate. Medium bodied. Better than average pale lager.

Definetly noe of the better pale lagers. Classic look, and a well rounded dusty/grassy hob aroma. Also has some acidic notes that follows into the flavor, along with a pleasent hob bitteness. Easy to drink, with a smooth taste.
HEY IF THERE’S NO OTHER  BEER AROUND DRINK THIS. IT TASTES CLEAN WILL GO WITH FOOD AND GIVE YOU A DECENT BUZZ. SORRY IN ALL HONESTY THAT IS ALL I CAN SAY.
Very light feel and aroma, the flavor needs food because by itself it leaves you aching for a beer, really. Harmless in small quantities.
This is for the special reserve, which wasn’t on the list. The aroma is kinda malty, color is light yellow. Wow really light flavor, perfect for the Japanese palette. But not for my American tastes.

I didn’t have high expectations for this, but it exceeded them.  It’s a new product in NB Liquor stores so I had to try it; there are now just too many tasteless beers to choose from!  thick, foamy head with lots of lacing,  heavy carbonation.  light amber color.  strong hop aroma and heavy hop taste at first which quickly fades on the finish.  Beats the case of Bud Light the guy behind me was carrying anyway.

12 oz bottle split with Jredmond. This shit is alot better than Kirin light.  this was pretty money and i might get this again.  Pours a light yellow. 
rerate on 4/5/08 - nose was a bit metallic and unpleasant after switching to this from saporro -.2
12 oz bottle split with Pwn3d.   Pours a light yellow. Skunky, malty, spicy and not that refreshing.

[502-20070810] Tap @ TFOB (Toronto, ON). Light floral and wheat aroma. Clear, orange yellow body with a quick bubbly white head. Lightly buttered yeast flavour with some wheat. Medium-light body. Not repeatable.
33 cl bottle. 5% ABV. Golden color, fine white head. It´s bittersour with some sweetness. Dry finish. Not very good.
I’ve had this a beer a while ago and never rated it.  It was as bad as I remember.  No outstanding features other than a bad metallic aftertaste.  Makes cheap American beer seem like premium.

A nice light golden color with almost no head and just a bit of carbonation activity.  I expected rice to show up as an adjunct but both flavor and aroma indicate corn.  It is slightly tart and crisp and in the mouth has some effervescence.  Although there isn’t much going on here it is better than I expected.  Definitely not the worst beer brewed by AB.

TFOB 2007. Bottle. Finally my laziness in seeking this one out has paid off and it came to me! Dark yellow body with a small fast fading white head. Muted sweet grainy aroma. Mild, sweet flavour, not much bitterness, with a slight not quite yeasty note to it. Average palate. Its pretty decent as macro brews go actually, but is fairly bland despite being largely inoffensive.
Bottle. Decent light lager with a slightly bitter taste, head dissipates quickly. Nothing special, a thirst quencher.
330 ml bottle. A run of the mill lager. Golden with a slight white head. Faded hop aroma followed by slightly sweet malt flavour. Forgettable.
Golden color, alittle hop, some sweetness tasted like a strange version of bud or something.
Surprisingly good, perhaps semmed better as I was expecting something in the Asahi mould. Much tastier, decent hops. Good amount of sweetness with a slightly buttery palate.
12 oz. bottle.  Pours very light golden color with white head.  Not much nose.  Tasted like a bad American Lager.  Malty with bit of hop.  eh.
Not a complete drain pour as far as pale lagers go, but I’d never have this except during sake bombing.
Has a better taste than something like Bud or Miller but still tastes watered down. Slight malt taste golden color, good with sushi!
Grain aroma. Golden color, medium head. Barley and wheat flavor. Vanilla hop and tin finish develops during warming.

Bottled 0,33L.
Compact and adherent head even if of short duration. Shining yellow color with discreet fizz. Light dampen grains, straw and malty scent. Bitterish and lightly watery taste with light notes of malt on the end.

Light to medium gold with a fair amount of white head.  Definite lacing as I drink.  Smell is of honey sweet malt mostly.  Taste is refreshing, slightly watery, with a touch of bitter and sweet malt up front followed by a smooth lightly sweet rice-like finish.  I really like this one, and it is definitely my favorite light lager.  Very easy drinking and refreshing with a hot meal, or on a hot day and exactly what I’m looking for when I want a cold beer to cool me off.

On tap with some sushi tonight. Is there ever another circumstance in which I’d pick this beer? Probably not, but it was either this or Newcastle. Anyways, typical mass produced golden lager, with slightly more buttery flavor and a fuller body than the average swill.

Tap, L’Orient, St Andrews. Clear ambery gold with a thin white head that laces a bit. Malt nose with some funky sherberty fruit. Taste is really straightforward lager mouth, really heavily gassed, with a really watery thin palate. Boring and nothing unexpected.

Golden colour, medium head, medium carbonation

Nose: a slight trace of hop and malt 

Taste: refreshing, sweet though quite thin, also minimal bitter hop traces 

The fInish is very short with another minimal hint of hop

refreshig, no outstanding attributes, maybe worth a try

Bottle. Slight unclear with a white fading head. Fruity malty aroma.  Thin palate. Taste is again quite fruity & fresh. Its thin like a lot of other mainstream lagers but it doesnt have Grain/corn & hay all over it. Light hops in the end! Drinkable!

Bottle; pretty putrid smell adjunct, corn and funk.  Color was as expected; clear and hay gold.  For the style, flavor was up there with the best, but we know what that means.  A little hop bite in the ending.
Japanese equiv. of AB or Miller.  Growing up in Japan, this beer gets high marks (for a macro) from me for mostly nostalgic reasons.
Golden, clear with a white head.  Smells and tastes like bud except maybe a little more sweetness.  Petty good.

Bottle.  Pour is pale yellow, thin white head, lots of carbonation.  Aroma is wheaty.  Taste is like a typical macro lager beer with a little bit of taste in the finish, dare I say a little hop bite.  Nice and crisp, thin, not much else.
Bottle. Pale golden, minimal head, typical grainy, hop aroma. Macro taste. Corn, light malt. Very mediocre, but when you’re in a Japanese restaurant and in the mood for beer, it works.
355ml bottle. easy drinking, nothing special pale lager. wasnt expecting more. didnt have any bad qualities but doesnt dazzle you in any way. very cool name and logo though
Yellow colour with floffy head who stays fresh hoppy taste,and short malty finish.My first beer from Japan.

Bottle,  Barley malt aroma.  Golden yellow with minimal head.   Slightly sour barley malt flavor - light hops finish.  High acidity.  Gets extra points for being the first Japanese lager I’ve tasted that doesn’t have a hint of soy sauce.  A decent pale lager.

I had a bottle of this during the interval of Don Giovanni at the Royal Opera last night. (Oh - get me with me la di da ways!). Suprisingly good - has a strong malty flavour, combined with a cirtrus twang. Shortish malt finish. Refreshing and very easy drinking. I’ve had this before I started rating beers, and unlike many other largers it holds up well.

Judged as a standard american lager.  Aroma had a very light sweet malt forward, no hops, and some off grain notes (rice, corn?).  Beer is completely clear, light gold, with a non-retained white head.  Flavor had a sweet, ’round’ malt forward, some more possible rice tones, corny, no hop flavor and medium bittering.  Had medium carb texture and an extremely light body.  Overall, it’s just too plain and watery.  Palate might be appropriate to style, but it’s not appropriate for me.

330 ml bottle, bought in Norway at Vinmonopolet. ABV is 5.0%. Brewed by "Wells & Young’s Brewing Co. Ltd., Bedford, UK for and under license from Kirin Brewery Co. Ltd., Tokyo, Japan". Website www.kirineurope.com . Crystal clear very pale golden colour, large and lingering head. Fairly strong sweetish fruity and flowery aroma, notes of artificial candy, hints of grass and honey. Fairly bland and dry flavour but not offensive, very moderate hops. Moderate carbonation, soft mouthfeel. Not very interesting.
Thin, not very flavorful, very light skunk and adjunct, foamy, clean. Would probably be a total drain pour had it not been accompanied by a bowl of red curry soup.

From a can. Pours a nice golden colour with a thin white head that quickly dissipates. Heavily carbonated, so big bubbles form on the side of the glass and then pop up to the surface whilst the head lasts. Flavour from the can is terrible; aluminium dominates the taste and turns a good bitter beer into a metallic tang that conveys no pleasure to the drinker. Palate is fizzy pop, unpleasantly thin. Overall: good when on tap, in a can it’s crap.

Bottle, poured a pale gold with a lot of carbonation and a foamy white head. A grainy malt aroma, a bit skunkish. The palate was not as dry as I expected (or as I find with other Japanese beers), or as hoppy. A little bland on the flavour side, but not as offensive as I find most lagers.

Bottle. Golden color, nice white head, but disappear quicly. Weak aroma and bitter flavor.

Cerveja dourada com uma espuma densa que some rápido, aroma fraco e sabor amargo e refrescante.
There’s just not much to this beer. it just a standard pale ale with noticeable rice adjuncts.for the hard Japanese party drinkers
This overly carbonated beer smells of faint honey and old skunk.  Gold body with faint head.  Stale grain taste with old honey. Metallic aftertaste.
Bottle. Rice and grain in the aroma. Almost neutral flavor, maybe a hint of hopbitterness in the aftertaste, but don’t expect too much of it. Clean and boring.

Bottle. Clear pale golden colr with a average fizzy fair lacing mostly diminshing white head. Aroma is light malty, toasted. Flavor is moderate sweet and light bitter with a short duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft.
Reminded me alot of budweiser on draught, really nothing much to comment on. Wouldn’t buy it again.
Bottle. Pale yellow colour with a white head. Cauliflower aroma. Flavour of vegetables.

Bottle.  Pour is golden with a big fluffy white head.  The aroma is corn, barley and faint hops.  Taste is macro lager with a decidedly rice flavor.  The appearance was the highlight of this one.  When at a Japanese restaurant I prefer Asahi.

Not so bad like the most brazilian pilsens. But it is not a great beer!
Poor aroma. Palate of barley and a little bit hops. Good appearance, with a golden color and a nice white head.
I tend to drink this beer with sushi and it goes well.  Not worth drinking without food, however. A step above American Pilsners.

355 ml bottle. Pale golden colour with a mostly diminishing fizzy and creamy white head. Grainy, honey, and floral aroma. Toasty malt sweetness quickly gives way to a floral and perfumed bitter finish. Light bodied, prickly but refreshing. I can see this being okay with sushi, but on its own it is average at best.
Blah. Blah blah. I can’t really comment on this. I dunno why I expected more, but I did. It wasn’t bad, but wasn’t stellar either

Watery, bow-shaped golden trumpet in ’Giraffe’ on the South Bank. But I’ve tipped plenty down my neck in The Japans. Faintly doughy maltiness, but a surprisingly robust bitterness more than capable of holding its own against a chilli and ginger mushroom  stir fry.
Not bad, but not very good.  Light honey tones, but tasted very similar to american macro brews like Bud and Miller.
12 oz bottle.  Not very exciting.... another japansese beer trying to compete with American Lagers...  Why?

Smell is average cheapo American style lager - unremarkable and inoffensive.  Golden lager color with decent head retention.  Thicker in the mouth than a lot of similar beers.  Flavor is bland, with a bit less adjuncts and a tad bit more hop presence than BMC.  Its relatively pleasant and easy to drink.  I’ve had worse, but doesn’t seem like something that anyone would have a reason to seek out.
Bottle. Clear yellow colour with small white mostly diminishing head. Malty aroma. Sweet flavor. booring

In Taiwan this is 5.5 abv. Can. Relatively good pale lager. Grassy hop flavor and aroma. Full, malty mouthfeel. A tiny bit of bitterness in the finish. Note: Kirin may export a different "Ichiban" to Taiwan as the flavor was quite different from that described by other raters and the the abv was different, as well.

For being a pale lager, it was surprisingly good. Aroma is crisp, a little grainy, but not too much adjunct. Flavor is slightly bready sweet, but not alot. It is mostly crisp. Not too much going on here, but a nice palate cleanser with spicy foods.
very pale yellow coloured ale, with a light laggey hop, mellow and juicy, a good lager.

Bottle.  Brewed by A-B in LA?!  Brown glass, but skunky nonetheless.  Lightly sweet.  Clear golden body with a creamy eggshell head.  Body is pure watery.  Light grainy bitterness with a touch of stale malt.  Soft.  Sampled in a side-by-side, I’d usually take this over the sharper Siwo, the extreme softness here is quite redeeming.

Aroma is slightly skunky when warm but nonexistent when cold.  Quick dissipating head of one finger on golden amber body.  Rich, malty flavor, few hops and a sweet finish complements any meal but is boring on its own.  Nice, rich mouthfeel.  So far, this is my favorite japanese beer.
Better than super dry. A bit more frothy and pale. A little bit lighter taste i guess but still pretty decent. Dunno where they got that can in the pic... special edition? looks cool though.
Fine with food, pours with a head that almost immediately dissapeared, I wouldnt be drinking this other than in a Japanese restaurant
A staple of any sushi restaurant.  Not bad, but really lacking in flavor.  Pours clear with a good amount of head that goes away quickly.
Had this with my dinner at a thai restaurant. It went pretty well with the food but nothing I would drink normally. A descent pale  lager with a lot of carbonation.

Light clear golden color with pretty much no head. Just your run of the mill pale lager aroma. Light malts, wheat, barley and light citrus. After a couple of minutes the aroma vanishes. Flavor is........ There is none. It is not horrible. In a pinch I might even drink it again.
Good flavor, nice aroma, and a great big bottle.  An excellent beer to order with sushi.
had it on tap at jolly gardner in putney, slightly fruity and easy to drink, not too gassy.
Not very good.  Tasted almost just like Budweiser.  It was good with sushi, but I couldn’t drink this alone.  Color wasn’t too bad for the style however.   Head also lasted well.

12 oz bottle...golden copper color, more copper though...smells like a beer...a tad of yeast...not awful...not great...its just a pilsner...drink it at your next party..go on ..its fine for what it is

12 oz brown bottle.  Pop the lid and you get an ever so slight yeasty beer aroma with a little skunk cabbage mixed in.  When I saw AB on the side I immediately thought of the many other pale yellow lagers they brew.  I was hoping for Japan when I selected this but now I see it may have been made in LA. Ubiquitous pale yellow lager color, with streams of bubbles constantly rising within.  Small thin white foam on top. Taste is a little different, it’s own personality.  Not real offensive on the buds but it does possess a low bitterness.  Just enough bitter duende to keep your attention. Finish is rather well behaved but  has a tinge of medicinal quality in a linger that lasts for a few moments. Over all not bad, however, there are many other domestic beers that meet or exceed the tasteful qualities of this beer. One much better lager that comes to mind is Schmidt’s. Does not taste much like bud or other AB lagers.
Bottle. Colour like dark straw, with some head. Indistinct taste, thin-bodied. Somewhat sweet, but bitter aftertaste.

Sampled at the Renaissance Festival. My favorite pale lager overall besides Heineken. Pours an amber color with a fizzy white head. Aroma of citrus and malt. Light, watery mouthfeel. Finish is citrus, malt, and a little hops. Pales in comparison to many other beers, but I would choose this over any other pale lager except for Heineken if forced to do so.
Large can.Clear brown-yellow.light malty aroma.not a lot of flavor,a bit thin.Slightly dry finish.Not very memorable.
Sampled with some sushi. Overall not bad. Very weak on flavor and color as it was very light brownish yellow. It goes down smooth and can be sake bombed but as a solo beer its not great.
Pale. Sweetish aroma, sweetish maltiness, few hops. Nothing special, but less offensive than many macros.

Bottle. Pale yellow colour. Small white foamy head. No lacing. Aroma was light fruit, some hay, grain, light hops. Light bodied, with a thin texture. Flavour was sweet, with some balancing bitterness. Slight dry finish. Ok I guess.
Bottled. A clear blonde beer with a decent head. The aroma is very sweet and malty and teh flavour is similar, with really no bitter aftertste like the label says.

(Bottle) Pours clear, light golden. Malty aroma with grass, hay and some sweeet corn. Malty, light grainy flavour with hoppy notes. Pretty clean with very light to no bitterness. Light bready finish. Small hints of funky herbes in both the aroma and flavour. Light body. A small plus for the clean-ishess, but I rather take my sushi with a Kaggen.
Bottle. Pleasant sweet version from these Japanese brewery with a neutral aftertaste.

Tap, Cape of Good Hope, Oxford. Pale gold, pure white cap. Almost no aroma--smallest touch of herbal hops. Flavor is dry and soft, but so very neutral there is just about nothing to put your finger on. Some very inoffensive clean malt. This is beer at its most precise, safe, and boring. You could drink this all night. But...why bother? Why not drink water?
Somewhat refreshing, the taste is unoffensive, and has a bit of a sharpness to it, but no - this is not a good beer by any means...
not much taste. another alternative for the sake bomb. horrible when warm. very malty taste. no head.
Pours a clear golden color with a medium white head. A slight malty and grassy aroma. Watery. No bitter aftertaste.
Bottle.Golden colour with a white head. Aroma is fruit, malt. Flavour is fruit, malt, grass.Thin

Another light lager.  Indistinquished.  Would give me a headache if I had more than one.  Decent with sushi but I bet a nice pale ale would be better.  Too bad most sushi places don’t serve micro brews.
Beer had a pretty neutral taste to it, with a little bite at the end. Enjoyable enough to have with dinner.

The sample I has was bottled,  brewed by Charles Wells of Bedford England.
Had a very clean taste with high carbonation. Finish to me is bitter, not a bad beer really.

Just like the Kirin lager this is a very average pale lager, basically your run-of-the-mill lager beer, but still better than Bud or Coors, and this goes pretty well with sushi, mainly because this has pretty neutral flavors, corn & rice in the nose & flavors, slight hint of hops toward the finish
There aren’t many times that I can’t even finish the pint.  I left this crap in the glass.  Stay away.
"Ichiban" means "number one" in Japanese - a bit of a pretentious name for a beer that is really more mediocre than outstanding. Not a bad beer, just average.

Bottled. Clear, almost golden beer with a small white head. The aroma is weak, with just some fruity notes. The flavor is weak as well, with some fruityness, hops, grass and malty hints. Medium body and a hop-fruity finish. Could’ve used a lot more of everything. (070106)

Botlle 0.33L.
Clear yellow body (very pale) with a small, fizzy, white head, fully diminishing with no lacing.
Aroma is very faint with some sweet notes and some herbal hints of hops.
Flavour is somehow bitter-sweet, but very attenuated: watery.
Light body with a watery structure; lively carbonation and light metallic feeling in the finish.
Not satisfactory; watery.

Bottle.  Pours yellow with a small head.  This beer always tastes skunky to me and I’ve had multiple bottles and they are fresh so something is not right there.  Pretty watery and flavorless.  Could be somewhat refreshing if it weren’t so skunky.

Rater-friendly 135ml can.  Unnecessarily large and frothy head.  Always scary, because you know it’s unnatural.  Clear yellow color, VERY light.  Pretty weak aroma of corn, grass, and a bit of hops, and some mysterious sweetness.  Strangely sour, yet slightly bittersweet flavors.  Vaguely interesting, but still so much like any other macro-brewed pale lager, that it’s just not worth drinking unless there are no other options.

Bottled.  Brewed by Wells and Young England.  A very pale yellow coloured lager with no head.  Nasty skunky, corny aroma which is very unwelcoming.  The taste is better with some bittering crisp hops and some smooth flavours.  Still not anything Id seek out, but at least it doesn’t taste how it smells.

Pale golden in colour, lingering white head, great lacing.  The aroma is grainy, herbal, grassy, crisp and sweet.  The flavour was crisp, sweet, some grassy hops, some corn.  Watery mouthfeel, thin body, medium/high carbonation.  Finishes pretty quick, grassy and sweet.  Basic and uneventful.


650ml Bottle.

Gift from by brother-in-law.

Production date April 20, 2006.

Bought a bottle at Martinetti’s in Brighton. Smells like Beast. Slightly hazey golden color. Super light taste. Has gross, rice-like after taste. Taste like old rice. Note: this beer was drank slightly after the freshness date. I can’t imagine anyone drinking this regularly.
(33 cl bottle at Haket, Göteborg) Weak malty scent. Clear golden color, white head. Light fresh malty taste. Medium to light body. Low bitterness.

Bottled.  Fresh floral aroma, pours with a light golden hue and small head.  Highly carbonated.  Reasonably hoppy lager flavour but with no real character to it.  The palate is a little thin and there is not much aftertaste.  A very average pale ale.
Fizzy and light, not much better than Miller to make up for the pricy import difference

22 oz bomber.  I’m not big into Asian food, although I have found that I am more fond of Japanese than Chinese.  I visited Benihana for a friends birthday, and so, I figured I should rate a Japanese beer.  Anyway, I digress.  This was consumed from a 22 oz bomber.  Pours clear golden with an average head which quickly disappears.  Some corn and rice scents.  Not an offensive beer.  Easy drinking swill and IMO very comparable to Budweiser.  Some flavor here which is more than can be said for many in this category.  Not a beer I will be buying in the future at around $7.  But it was worth a rate, nonetheless.
Bottled, light, no aroma, very little taste, balanced, but not much of a beer

330ml bottle brewed by license here in Australia, which is a bit disappointing. Light aroma of rice with a bit of hop to it. Gold body with white head. Easy drinking lager really, slightly skunky if it gets a bit warmer. Dry finish, bit of hops present, but nothing to write home about.

Pours clear gold with a thin white head.  The aroma is on the sweet side with little if any hops.  The flavor is sweet as well with not much effort at having much in the way of hops to balance out the finish.  I find this to be the case with most of these Japanese Macrobreweries.  Lots of sweet with very little bitter to the finish.
Bottle/draft.  Just a simple beer, nothing special.  Kirin is not my favorite Japanese beer but I do prefer the Kirin Lager to the Ichiban variety.

Free bottle.  Poured golder with reasonable white head.  Not much aroma... perhaps slight hops.  Flavor was malt beer.  Mouthfeel was cold and full of carbonation. Light hop and malt aftertaste.  I found nothing offensive in this lager.  Likewise, nothing memorable.  It was just pretty okay.
Bottle. Golden colour with a small white head. Aroma and flavour of rice, malt and hops.

This being my fist attempt at Japanese beer wasn’t a total disappointment.   Not a bad color when hitting the glass, but the head disappated quite rapidly.  The taste was somewhat sweet but I have no idea sweet of what.  If I was in Japan, I would now know one beer to order.
My beer of choice when it comes to the japanesemacrobrewries...has that little something extra that makes it that bit smoother and refreshing
May have elevated my rating because this went spectacular with squid sushi.  Very average but will order whenever Japanese is served.
Another pale lager that is very Japanese.  Still better than american beers but very light without a great deal flavour.  I could take it or leave it but it wasn’t really memorable.

Poured bottle.  It was very average all the way around, not a thing exciting about this beer.  Aroma was hop and malt.  When poured it was a golden yellow, with a small white head that was very carbonated.  Palate was non existant.  Flavor was a water down Bud.  Sorry not again.
Yep, not a lot exciting going on here.  Not sure if I should even rate this one but, here it goes.  Reminds me of Bub light with a different wrapper.

12 oz. bottle.  Deep golden with nice white head.  Lacing OK.  Not a lot of flavor, but at least it had some (re: Sapporo).  Malty, no discernable hop flavor or aroma.  Equal to the best US macro.  Compared to other choices at the Japanese steakhouse in which I tried it, it was unfortunately the best.  Not too bad, not too good. And definitely not "just right."

Pours a translucent goldne with an average bubbly white head that diminished.  Aroma was grassy, sweet malts, slight hop presence.  Beer was crisp, dry and refreshing.  Some grainy sweet malts, bread, rice and a light hop bitterness. Went alright with the sushi I was having.

I drank this out of a 330ml bottle not a ridiculous looking can like the one adjacent!  Like Asahi, this is a very dry beer, but almost equally as good and refreshing.  I have to say that it hasn’t got a great deal of taste, but that means it slips down a treat.  At 5% I could see myself getting well and truly rat-arsed on this on a night out with the lads in a Japanese city like Peking or Bangkok.  One might say that this is a kamakazi of a beer that could leave you with a Hiroshima of a headache in the morning given half a chance!!!
I liked it slightly more than sapporo.  all in all i think its a pretty decent beer.  dry and smooth.

had twice, today at CL hunan with general tso chicken, did not mix well...

pours a straw yellow colour..bigass head when poured at pace..has decent lacing though!..smell is just terrible, beer dumpster..subtle bitterness but is missing some edge..quite bland really, was expecting a little better but.....why???

avoid at all costs, just drink the free water instead
Bottle at Yamashiro, Hollywood Hills, Calif. A nice light lager, with proud head, that complemented my excellent sushi well. A tad sweet, malty with watery finish.

Clear golden colour with a white head that disappeares quickly. Light corny and grainy aroma. Very sweet malt taste with basically no hop notes. Light and fresh mouthfeel. Slight acidity with a slight metallic aftertaste. A nice pale lager for people who like very sweet beers with basically no hop bitterness.  An interesting beer in the sense that its sweetness would pair well with many light food.
Bottle 0,5l at Aki Japanese Bistro London WC1 15 Sep 06. Clear golden coloured. A small white head. Metallic aroma. Hardly any flavour. OK to sushi.
Bottle at home. Light yellow - white head. A very watery beer. Light malty, "vegetable", sweetness, some hop !?!! Not much of anything.

500ml bottle at a Sushi place near Holborn in London. Starts with a huge white head over a clear, straw yellow body. Nice lacing on the glass. Light and fresh mouthfeel. Grainy aroma. Served far too cold to spot any flavour - all with the exception of some sugar sweetness. Did not do any harm to the sushi food (15.09.2006).

I wouldn’t say that this is a good beer, but at the same time, for certain foods, this is great.  For example, I would never pair an arrogant bastard with sushi.  That would be terrible.  This beer is light, has not much flavor, but is just about perfect when eating something as light as sushi.
(Bottle) Pours golden with fizzy white head. Sweet and malty. Rather unbalanced with a slight metallic aftertaste. High level of carbonation, but low flavor. Nice to try, but not a very good beer.

CONTAINER VOLUME: 24 oz
CONTAINER TYPE: can
FRESH: 4 months old on a 6 month exp.
PURCHASED @: Jewell-Osco
COST: @2.00
HEAD: large white
LACE: thin rings
COLOR: Clear straw
AROMA: light malt
MOUTHFEEL: thin; foamy
PALATE: soapy
TASTE: like a light lager with rice not corn adjunct
COMMENTS: not bad, very nice actaully; 145 cals.  A-B is affiliated w/ these guys?
CONDITIONS:
MOWING/WORKING ON CAR- m
WITH FRIENDS- y
SIPPING- n
GET MY BUZZ ON-n

Bottle from Party Source. Poured light amber with an average fizzy white head that diminished slowly with fair lacing. Moderate sweet grainy aroma. Light to medium body with soft carbonation. Medium sweet flavor with a light bitter finish of short duration.

(Canned, "Brewed under the strict supervision of Kirin’s brewmaster by Anheuser-Busch, Inc, Los Angeles, CA") Clear golden color with a smallish, mostly fading head. Sweet, corny-grainy aroma. Sweetish, corny-malty flavor with practically no hop bitterness. Slight acidity. No finish to speak of. Light-bodied, not quite watery, slicky palate with medium, smooth carbonation. A very easy lager for those who like it sweet and hate the bitterness - not for a true beer lover, that is. Does beat a below-average bulk lager with harsh hops, though.
Bottle.  Japanese restaurant in Guam.  It was better than my Sapporo.  It is very watery but still sweet.  My favorite Japanese beer that I’ve had.
Pours a light golden yellow color. Aromas of grains and maybe some minor hop action.  This tastes like corn and sugar. Very watery and borring.

Canned(24floz/ approximately 750ml). –brought by a friend from New York. Brewed under licence by Anheuser-Busch, St. Louis, USA. No alcohol content and volume in standard european units written on the can. Pale golden coloured, small white head, slight malty nose. Lots of carbonation and not much of aroma. Slight hoppy and hay aroma with noticeable rice notes. Watery and mild bitter finish.

10/8/06: Bottle.
 Light hop nose.  Body is a clear yellow-orange with a white head.  Slight lacing.  Good amount of carbonation.  Flavor is slightly hoppy with a small malt sweetness.  Clean finish.
Um, tastes like typical foreign imitation Bud.  I did have some pretty good Sushi with this... I loves me some Sushi.

I havent had many Japanese beers to compare this to, but I thought it was decent.  Pour is clear yellow-orange with a lot of carbonation.  Fresh smell.  taste is slightly bitter, rice, wheat, little hops.  Little to no aftertaste.  I drink this any time Im eating sushi, which this beer goes great with.

not much of an aroma.  maybe corn and a little hop.  Clear golden in color with a very thin white head.    Very sweet taste. very watery.   Not all that impressed with this beer.  I think I would rather drink the light if I had the choice!

330ml bottle. Another Oriental beer, another weak, watery beer...in my experience the two are almost synonymous. Would have to agree with several other reviewers that it’s better than most in it’s class, but that’s not saying much. The best thing I could say is that it’s light, and refreshing.

(bottle)- Poured this into a dimpled mug. Great creamy head. Very pure yellow appearance, one of the yellowest ive seen. The taste has some fruity notes, followed by an aftertaste of malt. But it has a thin body, and a disapating head. Not the best brew, but not the worst either. Very drinkabe and above average for its class.

So many beers, so little time. Don’t waste time on this one. It’s ok, but like all the others. Yellow, clear. Medium head, white. Not much aroma, flavor has a sweet start, finish is a little bitter, grass.

Cold 12oz bottle, served along with miso soup and sushi.  Pours a clear golden color with a moderate light tan head, which dissipates quickly and leaves some lacing.  Aroma is of light hops and hay, with floral notes.  Taste is grainy and crisp, with light bitterness and a hint of lemon.  Fizzy on the tongue.  Ending is grainy with light bitterness.
330ml bottle - brewed under license by Charles Wells, Bedford, UK - light gold colour with lasting white head - no aroma, little taste
gold.  creamy head.  moderately sweet grainy malt aroma.  grainy flavor.  sharp carbonation.  man thats pale.  did they specially reserve this one just for me?
Straw yellow with little head. Some light tasting malt, virtually no hops and even less finish. Not great, but better than most.
Bottle picked up the ’Dodgy Deli’ on the Cowley Rd, Wed 23rd August. Pours a pale yellow colour, tastes bland, just about detect malt and hops if you try hard enough, but quite disappointing really.

bottle - Oh look, it’s yet another piss yellow, grainy smelling pale lager.  I did pick up a little hops in the nose too.  The good news is it’s better than Bud, Miller, and a number of other beers of this style.  Though maybe I was favorly biased because I was enjoying some good food at the time that I tried the Kirin.  The bad news is that it’s still not very good.  There’s some mild malt flavors, not much hops, a thin body, and a dry feel more consistent with the Asian pale lagers.  That’s about it.

Brewed by A-B in California and two bucks a bottle at the soon to be Brady’s now Old Chicago in Trevose, PA.    A little more bitter than I thought it would be, but other than that just another pale lager.

Draft.


Pours clear light yellow with a modest white head. Slightly sour, grainy aroma, sweet grainy front end to the flavor, metallic hop finish. Drinkable but not much more to say.



Revisit in Tokyo, Draft. Yeah, what it says above. Either I’m smoking crack or this is way worse than Asahi. Never would have guessed.

Bottle from Sainsburys, Charles Wells version. Gold, thin short white head and moderate condition. Low grain and slight fruitiness in the nose, a little butteriness in the mouth with a gentle chalky hop note and a short sweet finish wiith a hint of flowery hops.
16 oz bottle. Poured yellow with small head.  Nose of malt and a little hops. Bland, but actually easy to drink.  Better than Bud.
Not much to this brew. Easy to drink with a good, if not a bit boring, taste. Nothing stands out, but it isn’t bad.
Thin, slightly matly brew. Very little taste, with only a hint of bitterness in the finish.  Very unimpressive, though not "bad."
16oz bottle.Pours clear  golden  with a small white fast fading head.Slight aroma of malt and hops.There is a small amount of hops with some maltiness that is easy to drink but lacks flavor.
Mostly grain and some sweet malts, no real hops to speak of.  Unimpressive pale lager, but not awful like some.
Bottle (UK Version). Slightly sweet grainy malts, just about non-existent hops. Fairly drinkable if a bit on the bland side.
Clear pale golden in color with a small white foam head.  Weak aroma of sweet grainy malt.  Watery malt flavor.  Not terrible, but pretty boring.
24oz. can. Pours clear pale yellow with a white head. Aroma is malty. Flavor is malt and metal.

Brewed under licence by Charles Wells. You buy an exotic imported beer with dragons and Japanese characters only to find it was brewed in the English Midlands half a mile from your front door. Pale yellow with a lot of fizz. Yeasty aroma and an unusual sourness in the taste. Not the worst ever international lager.
Bottle, brewed under license by Charles Wells. A yellow coloured pour with an average head. A musty aroma. A hoppy taste with a hint of rice. a very light bitter finish. Average carbonation. Boring.

Bottle. Golden colour, with a white foam. Aroma of citric,yeast, and malt, and fruitines.
Thin body with yeasty, malty mouth feeling. Thin and short bitter finish.
Bottled.  Thin head, but nice yellow and almost green color.  Very malty with a really strong finish.  Strong sting on the way down, and a tad oily.  Would perhaps drink again, but not buy.

[Bottled (in Hong Kong, 5.5%)] Golden, average head. Striking aroma of green apples. Sweetish with concentrated juicy green apple flavour. No trace of adjuncts. The mouthfeel and flavour profile is strikingly clean, and it finishes completely without bitterness. Thankfully lacks the many off-flavours of the Carlsbergs and Heineken’s of teh world, making it a plausible choice of you want to quench your thirst without feeling any taste.
This is an overlooked lager.  Maybe the bottles I’ve enjoyed are fresher, but I totally disagree with the other comments.  This was crisp and no bad aftertaste.

Ichiban Shibori tastes completely different from a bottle than from a can. You wouldn’t realise it’s the same beer. There is yeast in the bottle and the sell-by date is only 60 days from purchase so it’s basically a "living" beer I assume. Try it from a bottle (I bought at mini-stop convenience store). Not bad by the low standards of Japanese mass-market beer.

12 oz bottle.


Clear gold with a fizzy short lived head.



Smells of skunk piss and grain.


Metalic flavor, creamy body, slight bitter finish.

  

Tastes better with a shot of sake and some ahi tuna. On it’s own not so good

bottle. big white head with a clear gold color. Grainy hop aroma. Grainy taste. Corn? Rice? Flavor so light I really can’t tell. ever so slight bitter aftertaste. nothing repulsive, nothing great. Take it or leave it.

Just below average beer in my mind. For a country that doesn’t sweaten any of its food, the two Japan beers I’ve had so far were a bit sweet. I just wasn’t impressed with this one and will stick to Saki when drinking imported Japanese alcohol. The sushi at the establishment I consumed this was quite good, though.
Can. pours yellow with a white head. Aroma of sweet malts and grain. Flavor is weak, malty, grainy, carbonated. Thin bodied, i expected worse.
Light yellow. Felt scratchy as I drank it. The little taste it had died quickly.

It’s an import!  It must be great!  Seriously, not bad at all, but not special either.  I found the flavor to be present at least if not special.  Goes well w/ dinner.  Nothing to justify the ’import’ markup though.

bottle. big white head with a clear gold color. Grainy hop aroma. Grainy taste. Corn? Rice? Flavor so light I really can’t tell. ever so slight bitter aftertaste. nothing repulsive, nothing great. Take it or leave it.
Can.  Yellow fizzy beer, unsurprisingly pretty similar to the other Japanese macros.  A bit sweeter than Sapporo and definitely than Asahi, but an odd metallic sweetness.  Nothing special.

The 12 oz bottle poured a sparkling clear dark straw colored beverage with a small fizzy white head that was mostly diminishing and left virtually no lacing on the glass. The aroma had a pleasant light malt character to it with subtle notes of citrus in the background. The body was light with a lively carbonation and a watery texture. The flavor starts off just barely on the sweet side. As the flavor matures through the medium length finish, it takes on a light, pleasant bitterness. The finish is crisp and refreshing.

Wetherspooons Beer & Cider Festival May 2006 at The Falcon, High Wycombe and from the keg. Pale, slightly cloudy. Aroma is odd and vinegary, a touch of butter - possibly old. Boring keg lager, thst is softly flavouired - and that is about it’s best featured. Bad.

Sampled on draft this beer poured a pale golden color with a small white head. There is only a faint aroma with a vague macro-ish element. The flavor is dry and nutty with very little body, no hops to speak of and no aftertaste. Bland and inoffensive.
HORRIBLE!!  Either I got a bad 22oz can that was cold, then warm, then cold, then warm, or something.  The only taste I got was that of ALUMINUM CAN.  After three gulps, the sink got the remainder.

This is truly a bland lager with no body and nothing that defines it.  This was my first Japanese beer.  The 22 oz can is special with a mythical half deer , half man on the side.  The head frothed over in the glass.  It settled down and the color was a clear gold.  I don’t eat sushi so I probably will not be drinking this lager in the future.

One of the better Japanese brews and goes great with sake and sushi. I sampled this with six other Asian style beers and this was one of the best. A nice malty flavor that is typical of the Asian variation of a pale lager. Quite refreshing!
Bottled, brewed under licence in England. A bland lager with no taste to speak of at all. Slightly sweet. Most places would have a better lager on tap than this.
Clear sparkling yellow-gold color topped with a fluffy crean colored head. Sweet, smooth corn and barley malt flavor. Average for the style.

Heavily carbonated, very light golden but not quite yellow. Sweet, grassy, a little skunky, all very mild in aroma. Starts watery leading to a bitter in the back of the mouth that fades leaving a grassy hop flavor. Light. Better than many in this style.
Very light beer, and of surprising quality. Smooth and easy to drink. Very little on the malt side, but a decent hoppy taste. Good brew.
Slight spice aftertaste, similiar to when you eat a whole lot of carrots,  nice gold hue, small white head. inital taste of maize and spices, slight hint of fruit

Bottled, alc. 5.0% (BB 08/2006)

Brewed by license in UK.

Pale yellow, small white head. Weak maize-corn, malty nose. Quite light palate.Sweet fruity maltyness. Also aftertaste is sweetish malty. Somewhat you can expect from Asian pale lager.

Bottled (5%). Golden colour, small white head. Malts in aroma, along with weak hints of maize. Strong maizeish and malty flavour, with a bit metallic hints. Not for drinking separately, but I think with food, especially spiced, it would be ok to drink.

Rather light, nothing that stuck out. Not bad, but tasted much like a light beer. You can tell that there was time put into the brewing process, the problem is that it just came out an average beer. Not bad, I got it at a Japanese restaurant, so it went perfectly with the meal. I would drink it again.
Aroma is like a pale lager should be, but with a honey, bubblegum tinge.  Body is pale, cheap head.  Taste has a like fruity flavor to it.  Not as bad as bmc, but won’t drink it again.
This was a very light beer with not much head when poured from a bottle.  There really was not much flavor and I would put this in the class of many of the macro pale lagers

I was let down when i found out that an American brewery made this beer.  Tastes like an American brew but much stronger and more bitter.  At times, almost hard to drink because of the bitterness and carbonation.  If you want Japanese beer, go to Japan.

had during a business lunch at a local japanese place.  not much expected here and not much fullfilled.  very clear, very light, aroma of grain or rice, taste is dry.  if this is the best of japan as the banner advertised, i’m a little worried for them over there.
Not a bad Japanese brew.  Very crisp, malty.  Hints of rice and corn.  I enjoyed it with Sushi and the artwork is good.
I purchased a can of this Jap brew because I wanted to try something new. After sampling this beer I realized one thing, the Japanese should stick to making sake and sushi. Phu-Yuk!!

Another watery, dry, yet appetizing and refreshing Asian pale lager. Good carbonation. I could taste the hops and maybe rice (?) while supping it. Kirin Ichiban had a mellow, squash-tasting finish. Interesting... Recommended with Japanese food. as it quenches your thirst.
Bottle.  Pale beer with a nice frothy white head.  The aroma is very yeasty and slightly dry, and the flavour is slightly dry, watery and yeasty.  Overall an average beer for the style.

Pours a pale golden with adequate carbonation and a white head that was quickly a film. Aroma starts inoffensive with grains and milky lagering yeasts, but adjuncts creep up the nostrils late. Light corn syrup starts the flavor sweetly, but a Hallertauer hop bitterness takes over for a moment before a quick dive back into sweetness. Mouthfeel is thin but sticky with diacetyl butters lingering slightly. I started out thinking this was a pretty good lager, but as it wore on it became only slightly better than the typical A/B offering.


24 Oz. Can from Dominick’s, Crestwood, IL 60445

Bottle (12oz).  Yay - another pale lager.  Pale clear gold with a decent fizzy white head, bubbly.  Sweet macro aroma of corn, rice and stale grain - fairly dry.  Tastes the same - sweet and harsh, grainy, mouthfeel is watery, harsh - ah, hell, it’s a pale macro lager, you know the rest.

Had this one at PF Chang’s damn good resturant...anyway on to the beer. Pours out a typical yellow color, malty nose. Not the same nasty sweet stale smell you would get from an American macro..cough cough Bud. Taste is pretty much bland sweet malty with not much but a slight incling of hops, which I was suprised at.

Cool ass logo, relatively lame beer.  Sweetish smell (hardly there) came from this golden headless beer.  Very little carbonation.  screw on caps are bad omens usually.  The taste has a light (i mean i only imagined it after swallowing) taste of honey.  Really pretty bland.  Inoffensive is a good word, because it wasn’t bad.  then again, neat-o logo, half deer, half dragon thing.

Pours a very light amber color with white head.  Aroma of grains, malt and hops.  Flavor followed aroma, but added nothing new.  Somewhat flat finish, but by far one of the best brews from Japan that I’ve had.

This beer poured a crystal clear little bit darker than straw color into a pint glass.  It had a 3 finger white head that lasted about 2 minutes until it was at about at a finger’s height.  After the initial burst of bubbles from the pour there are very, very, few left coming up from the bottom of the glass.  The head does leave some lacing on the glass as I drink it.

It has a very grainy smell.  I swear I got a whiff of Fritos.  Yep!  There it was again.  So, we’ll say that’s corn.  This one will not win any awards for it aroma, unless of course you like Fritos.

The taste was acidic and bitter, with no malt flavors at all.  I found it better to guzzle this beer than to let it wander around my mouth.  A guzzling beer.  I’ll have one more because I bought 2 cans as a something to drink while brewing.
 

Note:  I had this a long time ago when it came from Japan.  I liked that one.  This is really trash.  It’s very acidic, no malt balance at all and brewed by AB "under strict..."  Who are they trying to kid?!
An ok beer, I´ve drank this one at the sushi bars for years, as I did today, it goes well with fish, no offensive, easy drinking, grassy, lightly hopped, average, but consistant.
An okay Japanese beer if cold. So-so taste, yellow flavor. But at $1/draft in New York City - are you really going that astray? I would drink the first 2/3rds of one, then order another. :)
Draught. Clear golden color with thin white head. Sprucy, grassy hop nose with a touch of corn syrup. Dry, with a subtle but pleasant grainy flavor accented by sprucy hops. Nothing special.

Pours a pale gold yellow color with lots of large bubbles cascading up the sides and a medium amount of fizzy white head.  Aroma is slightly grassy and sweet, slight corn scent.  Flavor has decent body for a pale lager, basically sweet corn and malt flavors with a hint of dry light hops and grass.  Overall, not bad depending on your food pairing.  Goes great with sushi.
Pretty poor.  It’s Bud under a different name.  Maybe slightly better but still not worth the extra money its costs because it’s an "imported" beer.

(24 oz can: $2.79 at BevMo in La Jolla, CA) Date stamped on bottom of can: 22-Nov-05.  This beer pours a picture perfect pale lager to me, medium straw in color, crystal clear in appearance, with a few dozen separate streams of carbonation bubbles that start very small and slow-moving at the bottom of the glass, and as they move up the glass, they gradually increase in size and speed.  Mesmerizing to look at.  The bubbly, snow-white pours to over an inch in height and settles in rocky fashion to a thin layer over several minutes, leaving scattered patches of chunky foam on the glass.  But the praise ends with the visuals.  Grassy and lightly sweet nose smells like generic macro-beer.  Macro-like grassy and grainy flavor has a somewhat bitter finish and is further marred by a moderate metallic flavor that is strong enough that I am definitely not imagining it because this beer comes in a can.  Body is light, clean, and quite carbonated for a lively mouthfeel and plenty of sonorous, reverberating eructations.  This clean, macro lager really doesn’t taste any different than something like Budweiser, but Bud is far being the worst beer I’ve ever tasted either.  The biggest issue with this beer is the very distracting metallic taste in every sip.  But I bought this in the can for two reasons: so that I didn’t have to buy a six-pack, and because I figured the canned beer couldn’t be negatively affected by harsh lighting.
2nd favorite of japanese sushi beers.  Would like to do a side by side with asahi.  Creamy head, yellow fizzy beer.
[bottle from Ichiban noodle bar] another crappy pale lager. Aroma is faintly of stale hops. body is thin, finish is slightly dry.
Ratings are tough.  This is not that bad, and the bottle ads some life to a party.  But how do you rate an aroma on something like this...?  Overall refreshing and not horrid.

A dragon and a woman have a baby.  With a story like that whats not to like.  Except for the whole beastiality thing its kind of a cool story.  Alright the story stinks but this is a nice lager.   Easy drinking and non evasive this is a good beer with any meal.  The flavor is not dominating that it takes away from your dinner.  I only drink it when I’m having Sushi but I always go for this beer.
Bitter malt aroma with some hops. Crystal clear amber colour with poor head and no lacing. Bitter malt hop flavour. Very thin. Flat palate.

Good aroma for a lager, not corny, just malty. Orangish-yellow color, minimal head. Corny taste, malty, a little alcohol, but finishes light and watery. Has good body for a lager, but still a little thin with a little too much carbonation. Overall, I’ll drink it, but if it’s casual sipping I’m going for, I’d much rather have a Sam Adams or a Spaten or something.
Pretty standard stuff like most Asian beers, one for necking from the bottle.
Bottle.  Okay beer.  Not the best, but better than the average beer.  White head, yellow color, slightly weak aroma, "typical" beer flavor.
Clear fizzy yellow color with a frothy white head. Light grain aroma. Strong grainy flavor.
Pretty much an average mass produced beer. A little more flavor than a bud or miller.

wel done lager, like europeen ones.
.......................................

Light gold color.  Scant head, no lace.  Aromas of malt, miscellaneous grain, maybe rice or corn, citrus, yeast and a tad of hops.  Flavor was well-balanced, slightly malty and some noticeable hop flavor and bitterness.  Tastes all-malt but no toastiness or sweetness.  Slightly sour.  Reminds me of Ortliebs or Carling Black Label, for those who remember.
Special premium reserve indeed!  Such that its in convenience stores urbanlly everywhere!  Hoppy tasting for commercial widespread lager.  Nice finish.  (Note:  much better in the bottle.)

12 oz bottle.  There is really not much difference between Sapporo, Kirin, and Asahi.  All 3 are Coor’s light type clones.  I mean come on, do you expect rally good beer from Japan?  No, of course not.  You expect good food!
Looks and tastes much like a Budweiser or a Fosters.  Slightly more bitter finish than a Bud.  Nothing special about this beer, just another pale lager.
typical pale lage, perhaps a bit creamier than some. drink cold, if it gets warm discard

Absolute crap.  Possibly the worst beer I’ve ever had...and I’ve had a couple of doozies.  In short it was the same as all the other macro pale lagers...except somehow worse. OK here goes:

  Poured from bottle into a tall lager glass.   Pale gold color with a fizzy, short lasting white head.  This beer seriously smells like urine from some undistinguishable animal...possibly a nocturnal mammal.  After waiting a bit, it opened up to display a LITTLE malt, mixed with urine of course.  At this point I’m really beginning to think that this has been "recycled".  Do I actually have to put this in my moputh???  Dear God this tastes aweful!  A few sips and I was done.  DRAINPOUR.  I hope my septic tank bacteria will actually consume this crap.
Bottle. White disappering  head. Clear golden body. Malt aroma. Thin hops flavor. Tickling feeling on the tongue.

Well this one is actually better than expected. It has a grassy and grainy nose with some soapy hopelements. Clear, golden-yellow coloured with a thin, white head. Taste is sweet, slightly bitter with a watery body. Carbonated, just a bit hoppy, and mainly grainy.

From an 12 oz. long neck brown bottle with a "Freshest Taste Within 180 Days Bottled Date," 27/Sept/05. Made an average appearance, poured a marco lager golden with a small foamy white head that slowly reduced to a fine lacing. Had an macro lager aroma,

 grassy, rice grainy and pale malts, like a Budweiser. Moderate carbonation and 
a slick light bodied mouth feel, easy 
drinkability. Had your basic macro lager taste, a little grassy hop bitterness, 
some rice graininess, bland pale malts 
and a crisp finish with some grassiness 
lingering in palate, smooth tasting 
overall. This is your average macro lager in all aspects. Purchased as a single for $1.00 and I believe I was slightly overcharged considering what a six of Budweiser goes for.

Sharp aroma typical of lagers but with heavier hops than most American versions.  Pale gold body with a light white head.  Thin taste similar to Budwiser (not coincidental given this is brewed by their company for the US).  No malts at all and heavy hop notes in the ending.
Golden. White head. Sweet little bready aroma and taste. Watery. Not again...
about as good as a pale lager can get which is still not good.  Light, crisp, and clean.  Not worth trying.
24 oz. can.  Woot!  Nothing too impressive about this beer, other than the aftertaste.  Drinkable, but I won’t go looking for this beer.
Light golden, small white head. Sweetish, malty aroma, some corn. Weak malty flavor, some fruit. Thin and boring.
Bottle: Not much to talk about as far as aroma.  Decent head with little carbonation.  This is the Miller Light of Japan.  Really bland and watery

Draught.  Gold colour with thin white head.  Some dead pale malt aroma, some odd citrus fruit.  Can I taste rice and maize?  Certainly some adjuncts in this.  Then a sickly prickly finish.  I wouldn’t wish this on my worst enemy.  Too gassy and flavours are indistinct
Draught. Ok, let keep this simple. This tastes like corn and sugar. Corn and sugar. Not even fresh corn. Canned corn and sugar. It’s not good.

Large bottle @ I Love Sushi in ABQ, NM. Large white, frothy head atop a clear yellow body. Not that much aroma to pass along.. some grains, but that’s it. Light, unobtrusive flavor, but nothing special (definately not Special Premium Reserve quality). Yes, this does put out the fire of oriental spices, but not much more.
The only good thing about this beer is that it will cut through spicy flavors.  Nothing special.

Large white head of frothy bubbles.  Almost no carbonation.  Rice and corn aroma.  Nothing that special for a "Special Premium Reserve".  Weak, watery cornflakes and rice.  Medium gold in color.  No real offensive characteristics.  Can easily do without.

Bottle, in Gothenburg (040413).
Fully golden with a white head. Aroma light malty (corn, rice) and hoppy. Flavor light  sweet and bitter. Light body. My version was 5,5% .
Pours a light golden yellow color.  Aromas of grains and maybe some minor hop action.  Flavor was crisp, but sort a bland.  Still better than most lagers.

12 oz bottle.  Given to me by some Japanese exchange students that I hosted for Christmas.  Aroma of mild pale malts and hops.  Pretty much indistinguishable from any other macro lager.  Flavor is also mild and indistinguishable, though pleasant and inoffensive.  Probably a good sushi beer, I’ll give that a try at the first opportunity.  Not bad.

This one has a lingering maltiness which made it real difficult for me to finish. There are some hops and breadiness here and it isn’t very well blended. I swear I had a great Kirin lager before but this wasn’t it.

Cleam, sweet, banana aroma.  (By clean I mean not-adjuncty.)  Blonde with minor head, quickly gone leaving the golden nectar to speak for itself.  It spoke with a hint of honey, lager bitterness and solid blonde malt.  Pleasant buttery finish.  (I feel compelled to add that I drank this at cellar temp; I’m sure it’s a great deal blander straight outta the fridge.)

Pours an unnatural golden color with a fully receding white head. Aroma is corn, rice, DMS, and no barley to speak of. Taste has metallic bitterness and corny stale cardboard ’maltiness’.  Mouthfeel is sticky (nasty), light/medium bodied with high carbonation. Overall, when compared with Kirin Light, which I just rated, I have to say this is the more disgusting of the two. Being fuller bodied and more sweet just seems to increase my dislike of this beer. No redeeming qualities, at least the Light version was refreshing.  I decided this beer wasn’t worth finishing, so this foul liquid found a new home in the sewers. When will the pale lager pain end??

This is the best japanese beer iv had, and well though that doesnt say much this is a hell of a lot better than the others.Aroma is minimal, less corn than normal, more hops. Taste is littly sweet but a reasonable body for a pale lager, with some malt and hops saying something at least and trying its best to stay away from baked beans and corn.
Wow, a surprise! A Japanese pale lager.  What a miracle.  Boring though not horrible.  Just a normal beer.

Look, this beer is a pale lager, so you have to rate it for the style.  We’ve got lots of very crappy pale lagers here in Panama, and this one is MUCH, MUCH better.  I didn’t get the corn or rice tastes, I got a nice softly malted barley and very mild hops. Not bad at all for the style.

(Bottle 33 cl) British version brewed by Charles Wells in Bedford. 5,5% ABV in my version called "Kirin Ichiban Kirin’s Prime Brew". Fully golden with a creamy head. Soft, lightly sweet with both corn and rice added. Not much aroma. Or body. Or flavour. Or bitterness. But yes, it does quench your thirst. 260201
bleh, I should have just bought Budweiser.  Very bland, leaves a bad taste in your mouth.

Bottle

Grainy, ricey, some hoppy notes.  .       
Light gold.  Thin white head.  Lotsa bubbles.  .  
very light flavor with very slight bitter start and hints of malt/sweetness in the short finish.  .  
light body, watery, prickly carbonation.  .  
Summer beer!  Not something that I’d go out of my way for, but for the asian style, pretty typical
Well, maybe not the best Japanesse beer, and I think they are the best in Sakes. But although it has a good colour, the taste was not as good as you may think.

Picked up a bottle in Paris’ Chinatown (sic). Poured a pale yellow with some scum on top. Nose is a bit malty as istaste. Thin and watery.  Refreshing but not much else. Not a bad Lager, but nothing interesting.

Pours golden in colour with a thin white head. Pale malt and some grassy hops in the nose. The taste is not bad for a pale lager, somewhat malty, and more bittering hops than most other pale lagers I’ve sampled but at the end of the day it’s still a pale lager.
Bottle.  Deep golden with no head.  Aroma is malty and mild.  Taste is pretty malty for the style.  I had this at a Japanese steakhouse, and it went just fine with the food.
Light gold colour with thin white head. Mild malt nose with slight citrus hints. Medium malt taste with slight dry hop finish. Minimal lace.

Purchased can at Whole Foods’ refrigerated beer section and consumed within the 180 day freshness limit from bottling date.  Small white head that rapidly diminished and with spare lacing.  Clear golden yellow color with  clean slight citrus aroma. Light-to-medium bodied with lively carbonation.   Starts with slightly sweet malty flavor and finishes with a faint dry hop bitterness.  I enjoyed this refreshing lager beer with a seafood dinner.

Bomber poured a clear piss yellow with a quickly dissapating white head. Aromas of light bread with a bit of corn.Palate was thin and watery. Flavors of... just a minute I think I’m starting to taste something, yes... its a bit of malt with a little sweetness.

Sampled with some sushi at local Japanese resturant.  Pale gold with only a little white head.  Very light pale malt aroma, quite plain.  Fairly calm light malt flavor, a little bit of sweetness is present and there is decent carbonation activity.  Clean finish, but nothing fabulous.
Golden color with minimal white head.  Simple aroma and flavor.  Mostly malty.  Pretty decent.

24 oz. can, with the A-B "born on" date of 6 July 05. Well, what did I expect. Not much, but let’s see: Can’t deny it looks nice enough. Straw colored body under a fluffy head that seems to have a little too much stabilizer. Some malt, but just a touch of soapiness. Just has that same canned beer flavor of any other Bud. "No bitter aftertaste" generally means no hops, and that’s just what I get. It’s stereotypical of me to think there rice adjunct in this, but frankly, that would make it no different than any Bud, and that’s pretty much how it tastes, minues the trace of beechwood.
(bottle at a restaurant; not even from Japan - made in LA by A-B) Pale lager gold with rapidly fading head and almost no aroma. Mild malt taste. Not bad, but just a boring lager.
I’m definitely a Kirin lover. The finish is very bitter and strong, but feeling your mouth invaded with this great cereal taste is a good experience
Good golden color.  But no head and a very thin body, which i didnt expect.  The taste is bland, and a little too bitter for me.
Pours pale yellow with almost no nose, but good bubbly white head and some lacing.  The flavor is non-existent until you get towards the end of the palate, when some sour malt comes through.  Bleh.

So I’m sitting there drinking this and complaining. Saying how it tastes like a Budweiser but a little better. Then I’m reading the bottle and it’s saying how it’s monitered by the A-B brewmaster or something. Figures. No hops here really, some malt but basically another boring lager. Not offensive, less than enjoyable.
japan’s bud.  bad, bad, bad,  don’t buy it.  Bland, blah, and bad!!!!                                               .
pours golden with a samll white head, aroma of sweet malts kinda boring smell and taste, little bit of bittnerness, nothing great.

Apr-05  Very light sweet low malt and hop aroma. Yellow pissy colour with low head and suds lacing. Low malt and low hop flavour.  Stale light tangy hop finish. Overall it’s Euro-Asian trash.  It bellows from the street, ’Handsome Young Man’. My mate Terry’s comment is, ’...quite cheap piss’.
Did anybody notice that it says on the side of the bottle brewed by anheiser-busch under strict supervision of kirin, this was horrible.
Very dry beer.  This is a decent Japanese lager, perfect to have with Asian food.  Light but sharp flavor, dry aftertaste.  Nothing exciting.

Bottle. Very weak wheaty aroma, somewhat musty. Pours watery yellow. Thin head that lasts only a few seconds. Not much taste. Very watery. Slight bitterness in the back of the mouth. Very smooth and and easy drinking. Slight carbonation. Overall nothing special which leaves no reason to purchase this again.

Pours a med. golden with a white fizzy head. Nose of grassy hops and corn. Sweet corn pretty much dominates the flavor to with a dab of diacetyl. Body is med. light. but the sweetness blocks much refreshing character. Finish is quick and dry with no bitterness.
Tried these one at a sushi restaurant. Not that bad (would choose n some sake wine next time though). Quite light, weak finish
Japanese Bud with more hops?  That’s really all I got out of this one; fresh hops and a big dose of wateriness.
Pale yellow, foamy head, weak malt aroma, thin palate with very little flavour. When I finished, I found myself craving a beer.

633ml brown bottle. Poured a pale pineapple yellow. Nicely formed creamy white head. Dryish, crisp malt aroma. Rather average flavour profile - lightly grainy, faint sweetness. Hard to pinpoint any hopping, finish is bland. Cleanly brewed, but stripped of any character.

A pale lager. Presumably rice or other adjuncts used (except in the commercial description...), which means not much in the malt flavouring. Yes, an easy to drink beer, with "no bitter aftertaste", but unfortunately, I like flavour and an aftertaste.

When did A-B start making this u/contract?
This is not the 1st time I’ve had this beer, but it’s the 1st time it’s been brewed in LA by A-B. It might just be me but the quality has slipped a little  bit. Maybe I’m biased...

Clear golden, head is gone in 30 sec. Smells like Bud, tastes very light...goes very well with Teriyaki.

Review Update: So I’m trying to re-visit beers that it has been years since my last time tasting and this is one of them I absolutely hated when I first had it 7 years ago. This time around I had it fresh from a bottle at a sushi bar and not from some dusty old stock liquor store. Aroma is much more better my second time around with a semi sweet scent of bread and grains that actually smells appetizing. The drink itself is much more flavorful than I remember even though it doesn’t taste as refreshing as an Asahi or Sapporo. For sure hits the spot on a hot summer day and goes down easy with raw fish, ginger, and wasabi.
